From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Does Novelty Search Learn Exploratory Skills?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=Aq6eBj9spsAMQK9vIXXJ-YttCOQg0ewspVB20M-Y_TnkgihlszKe
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune


--Apple-Mail=_FE497B12-354D-498E-AEC0-E245316C6621
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Ken,

Please see below. 

> Hi Jeff, just a few comments on your pape=
r with Roby Velez exploring whether novelty search is like a random search.=
   First, once again congratulations on publishing a systematic and compreh=
ensive study on a delicate and tricky question.  I very much enjoyed readin=
g through all the experiments and because of that found myself finishing th=
e paper quickly.
> 
> 
Thanks. We are really glad you liked it.  

> The re=
sults in this paper rebut a viewpoint that naturally I do not agree with, s=
o of course overall the paper confirms my own intuitions.  In effect I thin=
k it makes a strong case that the information accumulated over novelty sear=
ch is arguably useful for something, so it is not random.  That is a nice p=
iece of evidence to have available and I imagine it will be cited often in =
the future for that reason.
> 
That would be great. We did think that it wo=
uld be useful for us as a community to have a paper documenting that Novelt=
y Search is not random, and that it does accumulate information about how t=
o explore its environment. Being able to cite such a paper might prevent fu=
ture Novelty Search papers from getting rejected due to skepticism about th=
e technique. 

> 
> The paper also raises some interesting further question=
s.  I can see one potential confounding question.  Of course it is not in m=
y interest to suggest confounding factors when I agree with the conclusions=
, but it's still an interesting question:  Is the information accumulated w=
ithin a network really evidence that the search itself that led to the netw=
ork is not random?  Or would any network that solves a task in effect conta=
in useful information, even if it was solved randomly?  That is, in short, =
what would happen if you collected networks that solve the maze that were d=
iscovered by purely random search?  Of course, you've have to do a lot of l=
ong runs of random search (because it's a poor algorithm), but still, would=
 such networks be any different in this regard from novelty and fitness?
> =


That is an excellent, interesting question. JBM raised the same point in =
reaction to this paper. I do think that any network that solved the problem=
 would probably show similar levels of exploratory skills, but I don=92t th=
ink it=92s a guarantee a priori because of the spectrum of possibilities I =
outline below. A related, but also fascinating question is this: why didn=
=92t Novelty Search produce more skills than the traditional EA? My guess i=
s that most people would have guessed that it would have. 

I can imagine a=
 continuum of ways to solve the hard maze. On the least-general end you hav=
e a open-loop, memorized trajectory that happens to solve that specific maz=
e: this sort of solution will not have any general exploratory skills that =
will transfer to other domains. On the most-general end you have a general =
solution to mazes (either explore everywhere or, even better on any maze wh=
ere you don=92t start out near the wall of an island within the maze, go to=
 the nearest wall and follow it). 

The solutions we found are somewhere in=
 the middle, but the fact that there is a continuum opens up the question o=
f whether different search algorithms produce solutions at various points o=
n the continuum. I predicted that NS would be further toward the general en=
d than EAs, but that=92s not what we found. Why not? I=92d be interested to=
 hear your opinion, Joel=92s, and that of the rest of the community. 

Even=
 more interesting is to think of whether other algorithms (or behavior metr=
ics, or fitness metrics) would produce organisms more toward the general en=
d. Can you think of any?

Regarding your question of whether or not random =
search could produce organisms equally as far toward the general end as NS =
and objective-driven EAs: as I said above, I think that random search could=
 do that, but only if you waited long enough until you happened to generate=
 an organism that did have such general exploratory skills. I think that is=
 exceedingly unlikely, but theoretically random search will eventually find=
 everything. But the same is true for evolution vs. random search: We think=
 there are interesting principles that caused evolution to produce complexi=
ty (e.g. hawks and humans), but random search would also ultimately produce=
 hawks and humans given enough time: but that fact does not cause me to thi=
nk that evolution is no better than random search at accumulating informati=
on.

> 
> Another interesting issue that you do touch on in the paper is th=
e difference between solutions from novelty and from fitness.  Of course, i=
t is not good news for fitness that it takes more effort to get similar res=
ults, but there is evidence in other works that solutions from fitness have=
 liabilities beyond simply whether they solve the problem or not.  For exam=
ple, there is evidence that they are more complex than necessary and eviden=
ce that they are less evolvable (e.g. http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/=
2011/lehman-cec11 ).  My work with Brian Woolley also hints that fitness-ba=
sed search can yield dramatically bad representations even when a problem i=
s solved.  We've also seen a lot of evidence of that informally in our lab.=
  Yet here in this paper whatever negative effect fitness has isn't showing=
 up very strongly.  I'm not sure why, but I suspect there are variants of t=
his kind of work that could tease out this issue more explicitly, though it=
 was not the focus of this paper.
> 
> 
I agree with you.There is some nice=
 evidence that you and your collaborators have produced showing that object=
ive driven search can have detrimental effects on genomic representations. =
However, as you point out, those issues should affect evolvability, and we =
did not see any differences in evolvability in this study. I think that you=
 rightly point out that additional studies might be able to find cases in w=
hich novelty search genomes evolve faster than genomes generated via object=
ive-driven search, and I hope that we as a community conduct those experime=
nts. I think it would be a fascinating thing to show over multiple problems=
.

> But one thing even now that we could potentially check is how large th=
e networks from the objective runs are versus the size of the ones from nov=
elty.  If that difference is like what I observed with Joel (which we would=
 expect since it's the same experiment) then that at least hints that troub=
le is looming for fitness even if it didn't show up here.  Also, we should =
keep in mind that the continuations you ran were with novelty (even if it s=
tarted with fitness).  Perhaps novelty is powerful enough to overcome the c=
orruption of fitness if fitness has not held sway for too long - this issue=
 is still not well understood or researched.  I have begun thinking of obje=
ctive fitness as a kind of corruption or poison that can be tolerated in lo=
w doses, but that becomes increasingly toxic to representation the more of =
the search it consumes.
> 
> 
We did not check on the size of the genomes, =
because you and you and Joel have already done that for this experiment. I =
agree with you that having an overly large, complex genome is likely to dec=
rease evolvability. To some extent that is what I was arguing in the other =
thread: that the parsimony/regularization pressure that you get via the con=
nection cost technique is likely to improve evolvability. So I have hope th=
at novelty search genomes may be more evolvable (much more research is need=
ed), even though I now believe, as a result of this study and the thinking =
I have done about it, that they don't have increased exploratory skills pri=
or to further evolution.

> Anyway, overall thank you for doing this study =
and making a useful point.  Even if the potential confound above turned out=
 the wrong way, these extensive experiments still show convincingly that no=
velty search is not producing random junk, which is a message that is usefu=
l those who are perhaps the most extreme critics of the idea and its potent=
ial implications.
> 
> 
Thank you for your careful consideration of this pa=
per. It really makes it worthwhile to spend all the long hours on these pap=
ers when we know that people in our community will deeply engage with the f=
indings.

Best, 
Jeff & Roby

> Best,
> 
> ken 
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_FE497B12-354D-498E-AEC0-E245316C6621

=3D"ygrp-text"><p>Hi Jeff, just a few comments on your paper with Roby Vele=
z exploring whether novelty search is like a random search.   Fir=
st, once again congratulations on publishing a systematic and comprehensive=
 study on a delicate and tricky question.  I very much enjoyed reading=
 through all the experiments and because of that found myself finishing the=
 paper quickly.<br><br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>Thanks=
. We are really glad you liked it.  </div><div><br></div><blockquote t=
ype=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); position: =
static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative;"=
><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>The re=
sults in this paper rebut a viewpoint that naturally I do not agree with, s=
o of course overall the paper confirms my own intuitions.  In effect I=
 think it makes a strong case that the information accumulated over novelty=
 search is arguably useful for something, so it is not random.  That i=
s a nice piece of evidence to have available and I imagine it will be cited=
 often in the future for that reason.<br></p></div></div></div></div></bloc=
kquote><div>That would be great. We did think that it would be useful for u=
s as a community to have a paper documenting that Novelty Search is not ran=
dom, and that it does accumulate information about how to explore its envir=
onment. Being able to cite such a paper might prevent future Novelty Search=
 papers from getting rejected due to skepticism about the technique. <=
/div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255,=
 255, 255); position: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=
=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=
=3D"ygrp-text"><p><br>The paper also raises some interesting further questi=
ons.  I can see one potential confounding question.  Of course it=
 is not in my interest to suggest confounding factors when I agree with the=
 conclusions, but it's still an interesting question:  Is the informat=
ion accumulated within a network really evidence that the search itself tha=
t led to the network is not random?  Or would any network that solves =
a task in effect contain useful information, even if it was solved randomly=
?  That is, in short, what would happen if you collected networks that=
 solve the maze that were discovered by purely random search?  Of cour=
se, you've have to do a lot of long runs of random search (because it's a p=
oor algorithm), but still, would such networks be any different in this reg=
ard from novelty and fitness?<br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><=
div><br></div><div>That is an excellent, interesting question. JBM raised t=
he same point in reaction to this paper. I do think that any network that s=
olved the problem would probably show similar levels of exploratory skills,=
 but I don=92t think it=92s a guarantee a priori because of the spectrum of=
 possibilities I outline below. A related, but also fascinating question is=
 this: why didn=92t Novelty Search produce more skills than the traditional=
 EA? My guess is that most people would have guessed that it would have.&nb=
sp;</div><div><br></div><div>I can imagine a continuum of ways to solve the=
 hard maze. On the least-general end you have a open-loop, memorized trajec=
tory that happens to solve that specific maze: this sort of solution will n=
ot have any general exploratory skills that will transfer to other domains.=
 On the most-general end you have a general solution to mazes (either explo=
re everywhere or, even better on any maze where you don=92t start out near =
the wall of an island within the maze, go to the nearest wall and follow it=
). </div><div><br></div><div>The solutions we found are somewhere in t=
he middle, but the fact that there is a continuum opens up the question of =
whether different search algorithms produce solutions at various points on =
the continuum. I predicted that NS would be further toward the general end =
than EAs, but that=92s not what we found. Why not? I=92d be interested to h=
ear your opinion, Joel=92s, and that of the rest of the community. </d=
iv><div><br></div><div>Even more interesting is to think of whether other a=
lgorithms (or behavior metrics, or fitness metrics) would produce organisms=
 more toward the general end. Can you think of any?</div><div><br></div><di=
v>Regarding your question of whether or not random search could produce org=
anisms equally as far toward the general end as NS and objective-driven EAs=
: as I said above, I think that random search could do that, but only if yo=
u waited long enough until you happened to generate an organism that did ha=
ve such general exploratory skills. I think that is exceedingly unlikely, b=
ut theoretically random search will eventually find everything. But the sam=
e is true for evolution vs. random search: We think there are interesting p=
rinciples that caused evolution to produce complexity (e.g. hawks and human=
s), but random search would also ultimately produce hawks and humans given =
enough time: but that fact does not cause me to think that evolution is no =
better than random search at accumulating information.</div><div><br></div>=
<blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255=
); position: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"positi=
on:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-te=
xt"><p><br>Another interesting issue that you do touch on in the paper is t=
he difference between solutions from novelty and from fitness.  Of cou=
rse, it is not good news for fitness that it takes more effort to get simil=
ar results, but there is evidence in other works that solutions from fitnes=
s have liabilities beyond simply whether they solve the problem or not.&nbs=
p; For example, there is evidence that they are more complex than necessary=
 and evidence that they are less evolvable (e.g. <a rel=3D"nofollow" target=
=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/lehman-cec11"=
>http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/lehman-cec11</a> ).  My wor=
k with Brian Woolley also hints that fitness-based search can yield dramati=
cally bad representations even when a problem is solved.  We've also s=
een a lot of evidence of that informally in our lab.  Yet here in this=
 paper whatever negative effect fitness has isn't showing up very strongly.=
  I'm not sure why, but I suspect there are variants of this kind of w=
ork that could tease out this issue more explicitly, though it was not the =
focus of this paper.<br><br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>I=
 agree with you.There is some nice evidence that you and your collaborators=
 have produced showing that objective driven search can have detrimental ef=
fects on genomic representations. However, as you point out, those issues s=
hould affect evolvability, and we did not see any differences in evolvabili=
ty in this study. I think that you rightly point out that additional studie=
s might be able to find cases in which novelty search genomes evolve faster=
 than genomes generated via objective-driven search, and I hope that we as =
a community conduct those experiments. I think it would be a fascinating th=
ing to show over multiple problems.</div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div=
 style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); position: static; z-index: =
auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-=
msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>But one thing even now =
that we could potentially check is how large the networks from the objectiv=
e runs are versus the size of the ones from novelty.  If that differen=
ce is like what I observed with Joel (which we would expect since it's the =
same experiment) then that at least hints that trouble is looming for fitne=
ss even if it didn't show up here.  Also, we should keep in mind that =
the continuations you ran were with novelty (even if it started with fitnes=
s).  Perhaps novelty is powerful enough to overcome the corruption of =
fitness if fitness has not held sway for too long - this issue is still not=
 well understood or researched.  I have begun thinking of objective fi=
tness as a kind of corruption or poison that can be tolerated in low doses,=
 but that becomes increasingly toxic to representation the more of the sear=
ch it consumes.<br><br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>We did=
 not check on the size of the genomes, because you and you and Joel have al=
ready done that for this experiment. I agree with you that having an overly=
 large, complex genome is likely to decrease evolvability. To some extent t=
hat is what I was arguing in the other thread: that the parsimony/regulariz=
ation pressure that you get via the connection cost technique is likely to =
improve evolvability. So I have hope that novelty search genomes may be mor=
e evolvable (much more research is needed), even though I now believe, as a=
 result of this study and the thinking I have done about it, that they don'=
t have increased exploratory skills prior to further evolution.</div><br><b=
lockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);=
 position: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position=
:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text=
"><p>Anyway, overall thank you for doing this study and making a useful poi=
nt.  Even if the potential confound above turned out the wrong way, th=
ese extensive experiments still show convincingly that novelty search is no=
t producing random junk, which is a message that is useful those who are pe=
rhaps the most extreme critics of the idea and its potential implications.<=
br><br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>Thank you for your car=
eful consideration of this paper. It really makes it worthwhile to spend al=
l the long hours on these papers when we know that people in our community =
will deeply engage with the findings.</div><div><br></div><div>Best, <=
/div><div>Jeff & Roby</div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"=
background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); position: static; z-index: auto;"><di=
v id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=
=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>Best,<br><br>ken </p>

    <=
/div>
